problem: Michael has never taken a foreign language class, but is doing a story on them for the school newspaper.  The school offers French and Spanish.  Michael has a list of all 25 kids in the school enrolled in at least one foreign language class. He also knows that 18 kids are in the French class and 21 kids are in the Spanish class.  If Michael chooses two kids at random off his list and interviews them, what is the probability that he will be able to write something about both the French and Spanish classes after he is finished with the interviews? Express your answer as a fraction in simplest form.
model_solution:
Step 1: Determine the total number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids from the 25 on his list.
Step 2: Determine the number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will not be able to write about both classes.
Step 3: Determine the number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will be able to write about both classes.
Step 2: Determine the number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will not be able to write about both classes.
15 kids are enrolled in both French and Spanish.  7 kids are enrolled only in French, and 6 kids are enrolled only in Spanish.  This means that there are 7 + 6 = 13 kids that Michael cannot interview and still write something about both classes.  Therefore, there are 13 choose 2 = 78 ways that Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will not be able to write about both classes.
Step 3: Determine the number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will be able to write about both classes.
25 choose 2 = 300, so the total number of ways to choose 2 kids is 300.  Therefore, the number of ways to choose 2 kids such that he will be able to write about both classes is 300 - 78 = 222.
Step 4: Divide the number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids such that he will be able to write about both classes by the total number of ways Michael can choose 2 kids from his list to find the probability that he will be able to write about both classes.
Step 4: 
$$\frac{222}{300}$$
Step 5: 
$$\frac{111}{150}$$
Simplify the fraction.

$$\frac{111}{150}$$
$$\frac{111}{150}$$
